(OK, I posted into another person's thread before because I think I want almost the

So I have a PC that's got XP in the 1st partition, which is primary+active and several  
other partitions in the extended for programs, data, etc. .  
Plenty of unused space to play with if I want to, and all partitions are currently NTFS.  

Inspired by the other post I saw here, I'd love to -add- a fat16 partition at the start  
and a bootmanager and maybe a few other good things for image and partition and  
other manipulations I might need to do for various reasons - call it recovery for the  
most part...  

So - if I add a primary fat16 partition for booting and recovery, and move windows to  
a logical/extended partition, IF there is a really good way to control all this then that  
first logical partition would still be seen as C:, and I think that such a move would  
work fine because all the references used by the OS would still be valid rather than if  
the primary stayed visible - is this correct ?  

My existing system partition could be 'moved over' and converted to a logical partition  
which is quite easy with a good utility like Paragon, which I have, and the boot info   
put into the new primary but pointing to the logical for starting - then it would seem   
the only problem would be to boot from, and then hide the fat16 partition, which I have  
not done and is the center of my query here.  

In this recovery space I could even have DOS with NTFS drivers too, and ultimately  
end up with a dual-boot system with XP and DOS and even a HDD-based copy of a full  
environment like BartPE or Reatogo or ?  

S0 - if anyone has done or tried any of this -exact- stuff with success or difficulties I'd  
appreciate any info and direction because it is not a small thing and I'd like to not do it  
blindly, please ?

And one "going astray" ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif):  
> One of the replies above also leads to a page which mentions booting a RAM-disk  
> based image of DOS with NTFS drivers, and that sounds very interesting to me.

The general idea is to have a "clear goal" in each topic, thinking you were in need of assistance about the latter I suggested you to start a new thread.   

If your question is instead the first, I can easily re-join this to that thread, or cross-link it to this, as you prefer. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

**Back to Topic:**   

The whole point is whether you want to have that FAT16 partition as visible or not.  

The "normal" booting mechanism works like this:  
BIOS-\>BootDevice (HD)-\>MBR-\>bootsector of First Active (Primary) Partition-\>whatever System file is invoked by bootsector  

Here are a number of very well written articles:  
[http://www.goodells.net/multiboot/](http://www.goodells.net/multiboot/ "External link")  

relating to the matter.  

One can "fake" a logical volume inside Extended Partition by correcting the "hidden sectors", thus making that partition "Primary like" and allowing it to boot.  

On the other hand if the Primary FAT16 partition should normally be visible and the only requirement is that the logical volume inside extended should get C:\\ as drive letter, you can use migrate.inf file, details and links here:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=125945](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=125945 "External link")  

The two things are not necessarily "exclusive", the latter is a way to assign a certain drive letter to a given partition and can be used additionally to the "logical volume inside extended" fix.  

Once you get the hang of the principles, we may start talking about suitable tools....:cool:  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: ilko
forumNotes.content:
If the primary boot partition is hidden, NTLDR on it still can boot Windows on extended partition. Then drive letters assignment should not be a problem.  

Problem arises when reinstalling Windows. In my tests I had 2 primary partitions, first hidden and active, second with XP. During new install Setup would make the second one active and place boot files on it. No idea what would happen when the second partition with Windows is logical.  

Hope this little helps.

Actually you don't really *"need"* **zomos** 's .exe. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

The info is here:  
[http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=19663](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=19663 "External link")

Making one with the provided batch or manually is trivial, of course you cannot change the Disk Signature or change start address of the partition without re-creating or correcting migrate.inf for next install.  

> A really cool idea:
not really an "idea", just trying to "connect" you, grub4dos' partnew command and the goodell's article:  
[http://www.goodells....boot/ptedit.htm](http://www.goodells.net/multiboot/ptedit.htm "External link")  
in a holistic continuum....![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

> Now with hardware and drivers aiming towards even newer OS's than XP I have not too

Allright ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), but although my crystall ball has finally come back from tuning, I still cannot see properly experience, background and knowledge of new members...![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif).  

...and, for the record, NOTHING discussed here is "peculiar" to "newish" XP, same applies to NT (at least 4.00 - 1996) and Win2K (2000). ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

Now that "terms" are definitely cleared, let's talk about tools. :cool:  

grub4dos is capable of doing whatever hiding/unhiding activating/unactivating of partitions you may need, start from here:  
[http://www.boot-land...hp?showforum=66](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showforum=66 "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?...pic=14\&st=1](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=14&st=1 "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=5187](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5187 "External link")  

I ***personally*** DO NOT like grub4dos grldr.mbr installed on the hard disk MBR as it will use some of the hidden sectors, thus I recommend using Terabyte's MBR and/or ~~OS-BS~~ mbldr:  
[http://www.boot-land...p?showtopic=334](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=334 "External link")   
which "stay put" in 512 bytes.  

It's up to you if you wish to use the additional (GREAT ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)) features of grub4dos, but if all you need is hiding/unhiding, any of the two "special" MBR's, the .migrate.inf trick and Goodell's articles should be all you need. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)

forumNotes.author: MedEvil
forumNotes.content:
My multiboot solution is, always to use an independent boot manager to kick everything of and then to have each OS in it's own primary partition.  

This way, it is way easy to reinstall without affcting other installs.  

You just set the primary you wanna install to to active, hide all others and install.  
After install you set the bootmanager to active again and unhide everything again.  

On a reinstall one does not even need to fix the bootmanager! ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

:cool:

OK. Got it. Mostly done now but for the tweaking...details follow - but first, an example:  

Some while back I was visiting someone who happens to be an IT director for a big co.  
and who was their net admin before that for quite a few years.  
Being a guest from afar I was told I was welcome to use his PC for email etc.  
I did some very routine stuff - webmail, news, weather, travel related stuff...then fate struck.  
As I sat there helplessly - his supposedly well protected, very new PC became a slave of  
who knows what and I, the user - seemingly had no control anymore at all. Really.  
I ended the onslaught by unplugging his network cable and I went and got him right away.  
Damn it, he says - now I gotta reinstall windows AGAIN ! And he did too. Wasted several  
hours getting it cleaned off and running in a minimal state again.  
This was a life-changing event for me. We spoke of it - and turns out it was not so unusual  
for him - either at home, or at work - but for me it stimulated visions of shivering horrors.  
Reinstalling windows and all needed programs ? Semi-regularly ?! That's REALLY nasty.  
Over time I'd observed that XP users seemed to have a much harder time of keeping their  
daily-use PCs running steadily than I ever had whilst using good 'ol win2kpro.  

Time passed and hardware now demands a minimum of XP. Doggone it; my w2k system  
is now also beyond tired. Time to take it all in and adjust as needed. One thing though:  
I will NOT be stuck with a non-bootable or inaccessible system due to lack of options.  
No way.  
Then I saw that other post here and my old noggin started considering the options...  
and here I am - what a ride this has been !!!  

So here's what I ended up with:  
2 primary partitions - the 1st being FAT16 with System Commander 8, FreeDOS, NTFSPro,  
BartPE, and something called MicroXP a friend gave me that was the best thing that could  
have ever happened !  
The 2nd primary is the existing/tweaked up XP SP2 that I already had and was using, and  
copied onto this used HDD to play with.  
The rest of the drive is all extended/logical space for data, programs, etc.  

I thought I could EASILY get XP to accept the transition from primary to logical and that  
was not to happen - it would boot and the drive letters worked OK, but trying to get it  
all together with a bootmanager was just pure h\*ll I'll tell you.  
I tried every bootmanager on the planet that I could find and they ALL had some kind  
of problem with the primary\<-\>logical booting combo, so I gave it up.  
Most then revealed themselves to have trouble still with multi-booting from a single  
primary with FreeDOS/BartPE/MicroXP, and those got dumped for good and all.  
Lucky me though - I remembered I've had System Commander hanging around so I  
dusted it off and installed it - Viola - that's the fix I needed !  
Best of all it hides the repair partition SO WELL from the daily use OS that I am delighted.  

Here's one example of a simple fix that would be made easy and quick now:  
Removing a bad driver file.  
I had installed a freeware to change the default (advertising, yuck !) boot screen - but  
it was not reliable and needed to go after it would boot to an all black screen about 1/2  
the time.  
I needed to simply delete 'vidstub.sys' from my OS in all it's NTFS glory - so to do this  
little bit I had to boot from a CD (yawn), delete it, and reboot (Zzzzzz). No more.  
Now I just start FreeDOS w/ NTFSPro, then Xtree (yep, really) - find it -\> D, y -\> do  
the 3-finger salute, and all is well. Total time spent - maybe 1 1/2 minutes.  

I now have LOTS of experience with LOTS of bootmanagers and I can tell you that I'm  
really glad that I started with System Commander back in the OS/2 days, because it  
even blew away BootIt NG and OSL2000 by MILES. I highly recommend it.  

OK - now I gotta get back to finalizing this gizmo - and this may be the last post I make  
anyplace from my dear old w2k system...how sad and wonderful at the same time !
